result.execSummary:
The defendant Joyce M. Schneider was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Substantial Battery-Intend Bodily Harm [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(2).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Ordered joint and several with co-defendant Darin Schneider.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Pay the costs of supervision.  AMENDED 3/26/15.  Court appointed attorney fees added.  They are payable to the Clerk of Court, and not to probation.  $400.00 on file applied.  Balance of $1,693.00 due on or before June 1, 2015.
Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, with the victim, his family or residence.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent. 

Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Defendant to write an essay for her agent explaining why she thought her actions were a good idea at the time, and why it wasn't appropriate.  How she thinks her actions affected the victim.  How she  would handle this situation in the future.

timeConds.notes: Sentence to start on or before April 24, 2015 at 6:00 P.M.  May serve on EMP according to jail rules.  May serve in Trempealeau County, with huber, according to jail rules.

Transmittal letter from attorney Frances Colbert along with Notice of Appeal and a copy of PDOAC

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State. Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Colbert.  Victim notification complied with.  Parties are prepared to proceed.  Attorney Colbert made argument in support of the motion.  Motion not granted without testimony.  Attorney Colbert called the defendant, sworn by clerk.  Attorney Colbert questioned the defendant.  ADA Inlow cross examined the defendant.  Attorney Colbert redirect.  Attorney Colbert called Attorney J.R., sworn by the clerk.  Court questioned defendant on her understanding of the waiver of attorney/client privilege.  She understood.  Defendant waived the attorney/client privilege.  Attorney Colbert questioned Attorney J.R.  ADA Inlow cross examined Attorney J.R. Attorney Colbert redirect.  No further questions.   Court denied the motion for postconviction relief.
e-mailed motion for postconviction relief to Judge Becker.
Sent request to J.O. to schedule postconviction motion
